mn29:0.2: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood
mn29:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
mn29:1.3: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
mn29:2.1: “Mendicants, take the case of a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
mn29:2.2: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
mn29:2.3: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
mn29:2.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
mn29:2.5: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
mn29:2.6: And they glorify themselves and put others down because of that:
mn29:2.7: ‘I’m the one with possessions, honor, and popularity. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’
mn29:2.8: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.
mn29:2.9: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and leave imagining they were heartwood.
mn29:2.10: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
mn29:2.11: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
mn29:2.12: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the branches and leaves, and left imagining they were heartwood.
mn29:2.13: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
mn29:2.21: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the branches and leaves of the spiritual life
mn29:3.1: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness …
mn29:3.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
mn29:3.5: They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for.
mn29:3.6: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn29:3.7: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity.
mn29:3.8: Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in ethics.
mn29:3.9: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
mn29:3.10: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that:
mn29:3.11: ‘I’m the one who is ethical, of good character. These other mendicants are unethical, of bad character.’
mn29:3.12: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding their accomplishment in ethics. And being negligent they live in suffering.
mn29:3.13: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, and bark, he’d cut off the shoots and leave imagining they were heartwood.
mn29:3.14: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
mn29:3.15: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
mn29:3.16: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the shoots, and left imagining they were heartwood.
mn29:3.17: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
mn29:4.13: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the shoots of the spiritual life
mn29:4.15: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness …
mn29:4.18: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. …
mn29:4.25: Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in immersion.
mn29:4.26: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
mn29:4.27: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that:
mn29:4.28: ‘I’m the one with immersion and unified mind. These other mendicants lack immersion, they have straying minds.’
mn29:4.29: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. And being negligent they live in suffering.
mn29:4.30: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood and softwood, he’d cut off the bark and leave imagining it was heartwood.
mn29:4.31: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
mn29:4.32: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the bark, and left imagining it was heartwood.
mn29:4.33: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
mn29:4.48: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the bark of the spiritual life
mn29:5.1: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness …
mn29:5.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. …
mn29:5.14: Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision.
mn29:5.15: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
mn29:5.16: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that,
mn29:5.17: ‘I’m the one who meditates knowing and seeing.
mn29:5.18: These other mendicants meditate without knowing and seeing.’
mn29:5.19: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. And being negligent they live in suffering.
mn29:5.20: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, he’d cut out the softwood and leave imagining it was heartwood.
mn29:5.21: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
mn29:5.22: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
mn29:5.23: That’s why he passed them over, cut out the softwood, and left imagining it was heartwood.
mn29:5.24: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
mn29:5.42: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the softwood of the spiritual life
mn29:6.1: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
mn29:6.2: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
mn29:6.3: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
mn29:6.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
mn29:6.5: They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for.
mn29:6.6: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn29:6.7: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in ethics.
mn29:6.8: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.
mn29:6.9: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn29:6.10: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in ethics. Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in immersion.
mn29:6.11: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.
mn29:6.12: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn29:6.13: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision.
mn29:6.14: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.
mn29:6.15: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn29:6.16: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. Being diligent, they achieve irreversible freedom.
mn29:6.17: And it’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible freedom.
mn29:6.18: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and leave knowing it was heartwood.
mn29:6.19: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
mn29:6.20: ‘This gentleman knows what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, and branches and leaves are.
mn29:6.21: That’s why he cut out just the heartwood and left knowing it was heartwood.
mn29:6.22: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.’ …
mn29:6.39: It’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible freedom.
mn29:7.1: And so, mendicants, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision.
mn29:7.2: It is this unshakable freedom of heart
mn29:7.3: that is the goal of the spiritual life, the core and the final end.”
mn29:7.4: That is what the Buddha said.
mn29:7.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
